Description: GRTS ID number of the NABat grid cell where the survey was conducted. This is also the NABat sampling priority of the grid cell based on the GRTS master sample, for example, lower GRTS ID = higher NABat sampling priority

A user-defined name (6-character limit) of the specific location (or point) where a detector was deployed within a single grid cell. Being consistent with site names from year to year allows for easier sorting and interpretation of the data. For example, if four stationary detectors were deployed, each within a 5 km x 5 km quadrant in the same 10 km x 10 km grid cell, Site Names used to describe the four deployment locations could be 'NW', 'NE', 'SW,' and 'SE.' Alternatively, Site Names can be based on a nearby town name, habitat type, property name, and so forth. If a mobile acoustic transect survey was conducted within the same grid, an additional unique Site Name, for example, 'DT' (mobile driving transect), would be applied.
Latitude in WGS84 decimal degrees.
Latitude in WGS84 decimal degrees.
Time when survey/deployment was started.  Monitoring night 1 start of recording.
Time when survey/deployment ended.  Monitoring night 4 end of recording.

Description: The direction the microphone was pointed.

The file name of the audio recording (*.wav *.zc)
The type of software used for file processing, auto ID, and vetting.
The four or six digit species abbreviation of the automated species classification from the software used.
The four or six digit species abbreviation of the manual species validation.
Time and date when recording occurred.
Your NABat Project Name is defined by the user when creating an NABat Project at https://nabatmonitoring.org/#/tools
NABat Project ID is a unique project identifier provided to user when creating an NABat Project at https://nabatmonitoring.org/#/tools
Sample frame of the GRTS ID

A user-defined 4-letter abbreviation describing your study area, region, park, state, or land unit. For example, if the survey is conducted in a park or refuge, use park or refuge codes (for example, YELL for Yellowstone National Park). If the survey is not carried out in a park or refuge, the user creates a 4-letter abbreviation for Land Unit Code based on the region or larger surrounding area (for example, SOCA for South Carolina, 3LMA for Three Lakes Wildlife Management Area). Note that multiple sites (Site Names) can exist within the same land unit code.
Name of person/entity that recorded the file.
Indicate whether weather proofing was used on microphone (yes or no).

Indicate whether unusual occurrences took place during the recording session that may impact the interpretation of results for example, power to detector may have been low, time not adjusted for daylight savings time, recording was interrupted due to dead batteries, filled data card, microphone or cable damage, schedule programming error, late deployment, deployment varies due to non-standard microphone mounting, incorrect detector settings, and so forth.).
Time when detector was activated to start recording. Note that this may be different than deployment start time
Time when detector was deactivated. Note that this may be different than deployment end time.
